questions.text: Which radiographic view is best suited for visualizing pathologies of the middle lobe of the lung?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lordotic view

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Left anterior oblique: This view can help visualize certain structures of the heart and lungs , but it is not the preferred view for middle lobe pathologies.
  • • Option A. Left anterior oblique:
  • • help visualize certain structures
  • • heart and lungs
  • • Option B. PA view: The posteroanterior (PA) view is the standard chest x-ray view , which provides a frontal image of the thorax but may not give the best visualization of the middle lobe due to overlying structures.
  • • Option B. PA view:
  • • posteroanterior
  • • view
  • • standard chest x-ray view
  • • frontal image of the thorax
  • • Option D. Oblique view: Oblique views are angled views that may assist in evaluating specific structures or lesions in the chest but are not specifically tailored to visualize the middle lobe compared to the lordotic view.
  • • Option D. Oblique view:
  • • angled views
  • • assist in evaluating specific structures
  • • lesions
  • • chest

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lordotic view , or apical lordotic view , is the radiographic view of choice for evaluating pathologies of the middle lobe of the lung , as it allows a clearer visualization of this area by projecting the clavicles higher and out of the way .
  • ➤ lordotic view
  • ➤ apical lordotic view
  • ➤ radiographic view
  • ➤ middle lobe of the lung
  • ➤ allows a clearer visualization of this area

questions.text: What is the common name of this view shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Caldwell view

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Water's view: Used primarily to visualize the maxillary sinuses , the patient's head is tilted back about 45 degrees so the maxillary sinuses are projected below the petrous ridge .
  • • Option A. Water's view:
  • • visualize the maxillary sinuses
  • • head is tilted back about 45 degrees
  • • maxillary sinuses
  • • projected below
  • • petrous ridge
  • • Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard radiographic view ; it may be confused with Stenvers or Pirie's view, which are used for different purposes.
  • • Option C. Pierre's view:
  • • not a standard radiographic view
  • • Option D. Towne's view: This view is used to visualize the occipital bone , posterior fossa , and foramen magnum . The X-ray beam is angled 30 degrees caudally to the orbitomeatal line.
  • • Option D. Towne's view:
  • • visualize the occipital bone
  • • posterior fossa
  • • foramen magnum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Caldwell view is an occipitofrontal radiographic projection that optimally demonstrates the frontal sinuses . It is obtained with the patient's forehead and nose resting on the X-ray cassette and the central beam directed caudally.

  • ➤ occipitofrontal radiographic projection
  • ➤ optimally demonstrates the frontal sinuses
  • ➤ forehead and nose resting

questions.text: According to Water's view of the maxillary sinus, the radiographic image is taken:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Obliquely

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intraorally: Intraoral images are taken with the film placed inside the mouth , which is not the method used for Water's view.
  • • Option A. Intraorally:
  • • taken with the film placed inside the mouth
  • • Option B. Extraorally: Extraoral images are taken with the film placed outside the mouth . Although Water's view is an extraoral technique, the specific positioning is not solely described by this term.
  • • Option B. Extraorally:
  • • taken with the film placed outside the mouth
  • • Option D. Frontally: A frontal view is taken with the patient’s head facing directly toward the film without any tilt , which is not the positioning used in Water's view.
  • • Option D. Frontally:
  • • patient’s head facing directly toward the film without any tilt

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water's view is an oblique radiographic projection used to visualize the maxillary sinuses . It is performed extraorally with the patient's head tilted back to place the orbitomeatal line at a 37-degree angle to the horizontal plane .

questions.text: Skyline view X-ray is useful in diagnosing which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Patellofemoral dislocation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cervicodorsal junction: This is the area where the cervical spine transitions into the thoracic spine , and other imaging views, not the skyline view, are utilized for its evaluation.
  • • Option A. Cervicodorsal junction:
  • • area where the cervical spine transitions
  • • thoracic spine
  • • Option C. Tibiofibular problem: Problems in the tibiofibular region would typically be assessed with anteroposterior (AP), lateral , or oblique views of the lower leg , not the skyline view.
  • • Option C. Tibiofibular problem:
  • • tibiofibular region
  • • assessed with anteroposterior
  • • lateral
  • • oblique views of the lower leg
  • • Option D. Hill Sachs lesion: A Hill Sachs lesion is an indentation of the posterior humeral head typically associated with anterior shoulder dislocations . The shoulder joint requires specific views for its assessment, which differ from the skyline view.
  • • Option D. Hill Sachs lesion:
  • • indentation of the posterior humeral head
  • • anterior shoulder dislocations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The knee skyline view is an axial projection useful for assessing the patellofemoral joint , particularly for the diagnosis of patellar dislocations and fractures .

  • ➤ assessing the patellofemoral joint
  • ➤ patellar dislocations and fractures
